Scala integration

Contents

  • SBT Plugin
  • Writing Resources in Scala
  • Scaladoc

SBT Plugin

Rest.li is fully integrated with the SBT build system through an SBT plugin. See Rest.li SBT Plugin.

Writing Resources in Scala

Rest.li resource classes may be written in Scala, for example:

**
 * A sample scala resource.
 */
@RestLiCollection(name="sampleScala", namespace = "com.example.restli")
class SampleScalaResource extends CollectionResourceTemplate[java.lang.Long, Sample] with PlayRequest {

  /**
   * A sample scala get.
   */
  override def get(key: java.lang.Long): Sample = {
    val message = "hello world"

    new Sample()
      .setMessage(s"You got this from a Scala Resource: ${message}!")
      .setId(key)
  }
}

Scaladoc

Scaladoc is supported using a plugin. This is currently ONLY available for scala 2.10. To enable the plugin in Gradle, modify your build.gradle files, adding a dependency on restli-tools-scala and depending on it the module that contains your Rest.li resource Scala classes.

project.ext.externalDependency = [
  // ...
  'scalaLibrary_2_10': 'org.scala-lang:scala-library:2.10.3',
  "restliToolsScala_2_10" : "com.linkedin.pegasus:restli-tools-scala_2.10:"+pegasusVersion
],

apply plugin: 'pegasus'
apply plugin: 'scala'

ext.apiProject = ...
dependencies {
  // ...
  compile externalDependency.scalaLibrary_2_10
  compile externalDependency.restliToolsScala_2_10
}
Rest.li

Rest.li is an open source REST framework for building robust, scalable RESTful architectures using type-safe bindings and asynchronous, non-blocking IO. Rest.li fills a niche for applying RESTful principles at scale with an end-to-end developer workflow for building REST APIs, which promotes clean REST practices, uniform interface design and consistent data modeling.
